sections.subtitle: Statements
sections.text:
A computer program is a list of 'instructions' to be 'executed' by a computer.
In a programming language, these programming instructions are called statements.
The following statement prints the text 'Python is fun!' to the screen:
In Python, a statement usually ends when the line ends. You do not need to use a semicolon (;) like in many other programming languages (for example, Java or C).

sections.subtitle: Many Statements
sections.text:
Most Python programs contain many statements.
The statements are executed one by one, in the same order as they are written:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print("Hello World!")
print("Have a good day.")
print("Learning Python is fun!")

sections.subtitle: Example explained
sections.text:
From the example above, we have three statements:

    1. print("Hello World!")
    2. print("Have a good day.")
    3. print("Learning Python is fun!")

The first statement is executed first (print "Hello World!").
Then the second statement is executed (print "Have a good day.").
And at last, the third statement is executed (print "Learning Python is fun!").

sections.subtitle: Semicolons (Optional, Rarely Used)
sections.text: Semicolons are optional in Python. You can write multiple statements on one line by separating them with ; but this is rarely used because it makes it hard to read:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text: print("Hello"); print("How are you?"); print("Bye bye!")
However, if you put two statements on the same line without a separator (newline or ;), Python will give an error:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text: print("Python is fun!") print("Really!")  # This will cause an error

sections.subtitle: Best practice:
sections.text: Put each statement on its own line so your code is easy to understand.
